title: Billy Hitchcock
text:
William Clyde Hitchcock (July 31, 1916 – April 9, 2006) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="infielder">infielder</a>, <a href="coach%20%28baseball%29">coach</a>, <a href="manager%20%28baseball%29">manager</a> and <a href="scout%20%28sport%29">scout</a>. In <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (<a href="MLB">MLB</a>), he was primarily a <a href="third%20baseman">third baseman</a>, <a href="second%20baseman">second baseman</a> and <a href="shortstop">shortstop</a> who appeared in 703 <a href="games%20played">games</a> over nine years with five <a href="American%20League">American League</a> teams. After 18 years as a coach, manager (of the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a> and <a href="Atlanta%20Braves">Atlanta Braves</a>), and scout he became an executive in <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">Minor League Baseball</a>, serving as president of the <a href="Double-A%20%28baseball%29">Double-A</a> <a href="Southern%20League%20%281964%E2%80%932020%29">Southern League</a> from 1971–80. His older brother, <a href="Jimmy%20Hitchcock">Jimmy Hitchcock</a>, played briefly for the 1938 <a href="Boston%20Braves%20%28baseball%29">Boston Bees</a>.
Playing career.
Born in <a href="Inverness%2C%20Bullock%20County%2C%20Alabama">Inverness, Alabama</a> and a graduate of <a href="Auburn%20University">Auburn University</a>, Hitchcock played all four infield positions during a nine-year <a href="American%20League">American League</a> active career. The right-handed batter and thrower stood tall and weighed . He broke in with the <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a>, spent three years in the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Forces">Army Air Force</a> in the Pacific during World War II, and resumed his Major League career from 1946 to 1953. Overall, he <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batted</a> .243 with 547 <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> and five <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s in 703 games with the Tigers, <a href="Washington%20Senators%20%281901%E2%80%9360%29">Washington Senators</a>, <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a>, <a href="St.%20Louis%20Browns">St. Louis Browns</a> and <a href="Philadelphia%20Athletics">Philadelphia Athletics</a>.
Managerial career.
Between <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> managing assignments in 1954 and 1961, Hitchcock served a six-year (1955–60) term as the Tigers' third base coach. He also became a footnote to one of the most bizarre personnel transactions in baseball annals. On August 3, 1960, the Tigers and <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> traded their managers, <a href="Jimmy%20Dykes">Jimmy Dykes</a> for <a href="Joe%20Gordon">Joe Gordon</a>. Hitchcock served as Detroit's interim skipper for one game while Gordon was en route from his Cleveland assignment, and the Tigers defeated the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a>, 12–2, on August 3 at <a href="Yankee%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Yankee Stadium</a>.
In , Hitchcock was named the full-time manager of the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a>. But in his two seasons at the helm, the ballclub barely broke the .500 mark (163–161). Hitchcock was dismissed on September 29 after the final game of the <a href="1963%20Baltimore%20Orioles%20season">1963</a> campaign in which the fourth-place Orioles finished games behind the Yankees, and moved into Baltimore's <a href="farm%20system">minor league department</a> as field coordinator. Then he became a scout for the Braves, whose <a href="general%20manager%20%28baseball%29">general manager</a> at the time was former Tiger player and executive <a href="John%20McHale%20%28baseball%29">John McHale</a>.
Hitchcock began the season as a coach under <a href="Bobby%20Bragan">Bobby Bragan</a> during the <a href="Atlanta%20Braves">Braves'</a> first season in <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>. But when they won only 52 of their first 111 games, Bragan was fired on August 9 and Hitchcock took over. The Braves won 33 of their last 51 games to finish fifth in the <a href="National%20League">National League</a>, and Hitchcock was invited back for , but he was fired September 28 of that year with the team in seventh place and three games remaining on the schedule. His career managing record was 274 wins, 261 losses (.514). Hitchcock then scouted for McHale and the <a href="Montreal%20Expos">Montreal Expos</a> in 1968–71 before taking over as president of the <a href="Southern%20League%20%281964%E2%80%932020%29">Southern League</a>.
Southern League presidency.
Hitchcock became president of the Southern League in August 1971. During his presidency, the league added new teams, expanded its playoffs, and introduced split-season play. Other improvements included stadium refurbishments and efforts to make the league more family-friendly. Attendance figures rose dramatically during his tenure, from 333,500 in 1971 to over 1.7 million in 1980. The <a href="List%20of%20Southern%20League%20champions">Southern League championship</a> trophy is named after Hitchcock, and in 1980 he was presented with the <a href="King%20of%20Baseball">King of Baseball</a> award given by Minor League Baseball. He stepped down from the presidency in 1980.
College athletics.
In addition to his baseball resume, Hitchcock also made a name for himself in <a href="college%20football">college football</a> and <a href="golf">golf</a>. As an All-Conference <a href="Halfback%20%28American%20football%29">tailback</a>, he led <a href="Auburn%20University">Auburn</a> to its first bowl game (a 7-7 tie against <a href="Villanova%20University">Villanova</a> on January 1, 1937). Later in life, he established the Billy Hitchcock Golf Tournament at his alma mater. In recognition of his contribution to the school, Auburn renamed its renovated baseball stadium "<a href="Hitchcock%20Field">Hitchcock Field</a>" in 2003. Also in that year, "<a href="Baseball%20America">Baseball America</a>" named it the best college baseball facility in the country.
Death.
Hitchcock died in <a href="Opelika%2C%20Alabama">Opelika, Alabama</a> at age 89.
